--- Frank Enos <fenos@...> wrote:
> Hi Erik;
> It gets stranger. In trying to write a simple set of test cases, I 
> discovered that the problem only exists if the exception is thrown
> from a 
> class named "PersistenceManager" (or PersistenceManager2...).That is,
> I 
> can't catch an exception in a test method in Junit if that exception
> is 
> thrown by a class named PersistenceManager. Renaming the class 
> "PersistManager" causes the expected behavior. 
>

Sorry to cut into the conversation here, but this does indeed smell
like a classpath issue.  You might try using JWhich
(http://www.clarkware.com/software/jwhich.zip) to unambiguously
determine which class file is being loaded, as in:

   java JWhich com.xyz.PersistenceManager

Mike
